write_readme.description: Write a README for the repository
write_readme.prompt: You are an expert software engineer writing a README for a code repository. Using ONLY the retrieved repository context, write a clear, well-structured README intended for first-time users and new contributors. The README should include the following sections: 1. Project Overview: What the project does in real-world terms. The problem it solves and who it is for. The overall scale and maturity of the project. 2. Architecture & High-Level Design: A conceptual overview of the system architecture. The main components and their responsibilities. How components interact with each other (high level). 3. Repository Structure: A tree-style overview of the directory structure. Brief explanations of the major folders and key files. 4. Entry Points & Key Files: How the project is started or invoked. Main application files, APIs, scripts, and services. When and why these are used. 5. How the System Works (Conceptual Flow): A high-level explanation of how the system operates end to end. Focus on workflows and data flow rather than implementation details. 6. Usage & Onboarding: How a new user or developer should approach the project. Any prerequisites or assumptions visible from the repository. Where to start reading or exploring the code. Guidelines: Prioritize clarity, accuracy, and onboarding usefulness. Focus more on real-world meaning than code internals. Avoid deep function- or class-level explanations. Do not invent information not present in the retrieved contex. If important information is missing, explicitly note that in the README. Write in a professional, friendly tone suitable for an open-source or internal project.
